learning_outcomes.description: Apply research principles and methods to understand scientific literature in clinical practice and health-related professions.
Evaluate analytical techniques used in quantitative and qualitative research in clinical settings.
Discuss ethical standards, appreciate cultural competence, and acknowledge Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander perspectives in the research context.
Apply research principles and methods to evaluate the effectiveness of intervention options to address clinical challenges.

Demonstrate cognitive, technical, and creative skills to explore, analyse, and synthesize complex information, problems, and concepts, and apply established theories and frameworks to address clinical challenges.
Critically analyse literature to identify research gaps and design a research project to address a specific clinical challenge.

Demonstrate effective communication skills to justify and explain theoretical propositions, methodologies, conclusions, and professional decisions to both specialist (e.g., health professionals) and non-specialist audiences.

assessments.assessment_title: Assignment 1 - Critical Appraisal of Qualitative Literature (Module 1)
assessments.task_description:
This assignment is designed for each student to conduct a critical and engaging appraisal of qualitative literature on a clinically relevant topic within their discipline. Each student will produce a concise, evidence-based report that summarises the available evidence and propose an aim and at least one relevant research question for a hypothetical research project with its potential benefits in clinical practice.

Students will be provided with two qualitative articles relevant to their given topic by their discipline and will be asked to write a brief report. The main body of the report should be limited to 1300 words, excluding the title page, reference list, and coversheet.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

Please see the Assignment Task Sheet [A1] for details.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The assignment should be uploaded electronically using the correct Turnitin portal through the course Blackboard site.

assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Assignment 2 - Critical Appraisal of Quantitative Literature (Modules 2-5)
assessments.task_description:
The aim of this assignment is for each student to practice how to locate verifiable quantitative literature on a clinically relevant topic in their discipline, critical analyse the pertinent literature, generate and transmit solutions to the clinical topic, and then to write a critical appraisal report to propose an aim and at least one relevant research question for a hypothetical research project with its potential benefits in clinical practice.

Students need to identify at least 12 quantitative articles relevant to their assignment topic, provided by their discipline, and prepare an assignment with the main body of the report limited to a maximum of 2500 words, not including the title page, references, or coversheet.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

assessments.assessment_title: Assignment 3 - Critical Appraisal of Systematic Review (Module 6)
assessments.task_description:
The aim of this assignment is for each student to develop ability to critically appraise a systematic review related to a clinical question and interpret its findings in the context of clinical practice, focusing on strengths, limitations, and clinical recommendations.

Students will be provided with a clinical question along with a relevant systematic review by their discipline. They will be asked to critically appraise the systematic review, with a particular emphasis on its clinical applicability, and to provide evidence-based recommendations in choosing appropriate actions to address the clinical question, while also identifying potential practical challenges. The main body of the report must not exceed 1000 words, excluding the title page, references, and coversheet.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

Please see the Assignment Task Sheet [A3] for details.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 2 To Week 3(04 Aug - 17 Aug)
learning_activities.topic:
Module 1: Evaluation of qualitative research including an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander perspective

This module introduces students to the role of qualitative research in clinical practice. It covers how to develop research questions, understand key qualitative methodologies, and assess evidence using concepts like credibility, transferability, and reflexivity. Students will learn to structure qualitative reports, use the CASP checklists for appraisal, and apply culturally safe research principles, including the AIATSIS Code of Ethics and NHMRC Indigenous values, with a focus on research involving First Nations peoples.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05, L06, L07

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 4 To Week 11(18 Aug - 19 Oct)
learning_activities.topic:
Modules 2-5: Evaluation of quantitative litature

These modules explore the role of quantitative research in clinical practice and across health-related professions within the school. Students will learn how to locate, critically evaluate, analyse, and synthesise published quantitative studies, including recent developments in the field. The modules cover key principles and methodologies of quantitative research and focus on applying this knowledge to enhance clinical practice. Students will also develop advanced skills in scientific writing to interpret, theorise, justify, and communicate research within health-related professional contexts.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05, L06, L07

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 12 To Week 13(20 Oct - 02 Nov)
learning_activities.topic:
Module 6: Evaluation of systematic review and meta-analysis

This module introduces systematic reviews and meta-analyses, explaining what they are, why they matter in clinical settings, and how they can inform and improve clinical practice. It outlines how these methods are used to address various clinical questions. Students will learn to critically read and evaluate systematic reviews and meta-analyses, understanding their strengths, limitations, and practical challenges. They will also develop skills in effectively communicating synthesised findings within health-related professional contexts.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07
